31.50.text:
Doubt is an inevitable part of life for every
one of us.

37.40.text: about other people and about the ever-changing world around us.

41.10.text:
Some doubts are easily resolved; with others,
resolution might seem unattainable.

46.28.text:
Some doubts point to significant personal
implications for us;

49.68.text: with others, the implications seem more abstract.

52.68.text:
In some cases, we might shy away
from investigating our doubts

56.42.text: for fear of uncovering realities that seem unbearable.

59.70.text:
But generally, we at least feel free to choose
whether or not to investigate.

64.17.text:
But sometimes, other people attempt to block
that freedom, condemning the exercise of doubt

72.26.text:
This practice is observed
in dogmatic, authoritarian ideologies.

76.78.text: Prime examples are found in the realm of religion.

79.60.text:
Some Muslim apologists have described doubt
as ‘a disease of the heart’

83.50.text: and cite passages in their primary text — the Qur’an — stating that true believers have no doubts.

89.86.text:
Some Christian apologists have denounced doubt
as a ‘a tool of Satan’

93.50.text: and cite passages in their primary text — the Bible —

96.46.text:
stating that those who doubt should
expect nothing from their god Yahweh.

100.37.text:
Of course, some theists will protest that
they’re completely free to doubt

103.69.text: and always have armfuls of questions.

106.13.text:
Some make themselves out to be
quite the irreverent rebel.

109.11.text: And if they are genuinely free, good for them.

112.17.text:
But look closer and you’ll find that many
of these folks aren’t as bold as they like to think.

116.82.text:
In fact their questions fit very comfortably
within a tacitly approved list

120.96.text:
of commonly voiced complaints that the
major religions have all developed stock responses for

125.62.text:
— however inadequate or platitudinous
those responses might be.

129.16.text: It’s when you depart from the approved list

131.66.text: — and the patience and compassion of those around you turn to disapproval and condemnation —

136.52.text:
that the fog begins to clear and the limits imposed
on your freedom become apparent.

141.84.text: Investigating your religious doubts, in the face of prohibition, can feel like walking an intimidating path.

148.06.text: A steep path that might challenge your most deep-rooted preconceptions, your integrity, your stamina.

155.00.text:
A rocky path, along which you might experience
criticism, obstruction and abuse from others.

160.88.text:
An open-ended path that may — or may not
— seem to offer resolution.

166.20.text: So why take such a path?

168.30.text: That’s what I want to address.

169.82.text: I want to explore this religious condemnation of doubt,

172.70.text: exposing some of the double-standards behind it and the absurdities they lead to,

177.06.text: examining the emotional blackmail that leaves some feeling guilty or disloyal for entertaining doubts,

182.82.text:
and explaining the very real dangers involved
when faith is unrestrained by doubt.

192.14.text:
When Abraham said: ‘Show me, Lord, how you
will raise the dead,’

198.23.text: He said ‘Yes, but just to reassure my heart.’

201.56.text:
Allah said, ‘Take four birds, draw them
to you, and cut their bodies to pieces.

206.38.text:
‘Scatter them over the mountain-tops, then
call them back.

211.42.text: Know that Allah is mighty, wise.’

214.92.text:
This strange encounter, described in surah
2, verse 260 of the Qur’an,

219.72.text: illustrates a common religious double standard.

222.36.text:
Whether it be major world religions like Islam
and Christianity,

226.38.text:
or pocket-sized doomsday groups
claiming to channel aliens from distant planets,

230.74.text: we see the same old division.

232.72.text:
There are the chosen ones, deemed worthy of
supernatural proof,

237.78.text:
the common masses who are simultaneously
denied knowledge but commanded not to doubt

242.78.text:
— a double-bind that produces
acute psychological tensions.

246.63.text:
Let’s pick apart some of the layers of problems
with this elitist system.

252.73.text: Islamic scholar Abul Ala Maududi defends Abraham’s request for a divine demonstration,

257.72.text: explaining that Abraham is looking for the

259.58.text: ‘inner peace that one attains as a result of direct personal observation’.

263.72.text:
This is a striking acknowledgement of the
inadequacy of faith.

267.96.text: Here we have Abraham, a religious character so iconic

271.36.text:
that Islam, Christianity and Judiasm are collected
under his name as the Abrahamic religions;

276.96.text:
a figure who, according to this story,
even converses directly with Allah.

280.94.text: And still he needs the kind of reassurance that could only come from a demonstration of divine power.

286.40.text:
So, why is he granted the peace of mind
that’s denied to ordinary believers?

290.92.text:
Maududi’s answer is that: ‘.... the kind of function
that ordinary believers are required to perform

295.38.text: ‘requires of them no more than believing in certain truths without perceiving them through their senses.

300.94.text: ‘The function entrusted by [Allah] to the Prophets

303.22.text:
'is such that they ought to have
direct knowledge of the truths.’

306.72.text:
Maududi argues that the prophets had to tell
the world they spoke from direct experience,

310.92.text: possessing reliable information that set them apart from others who employed conjecture, fancy and imagination.

318.22.text: The problem is, even if their experience was genuine,

321.34.text:
it would do precisely nothing
to set them apart.

324.30.text:
Imagine six prophets who each claim
they’ve been given a guided tour of hell.

328.44.text:
These could be the hells of established religions
like Greek religion, Buddhism, Zoroastrianiasm,

336.42.text:
For argument’s sake, let’s imagine
one of them speaks from direct experience.

340.90.text: How would you determine which one that was?

343.40.text: This is a supernatural realm we’re talking about.

345.88.text:
By definition, it defies all of our experience
and frameworks of reference.

350.88.text:
The fact is we have no criteria for assessing
the reliability of this information.

355.48.text: Direct experience doesn’t set people apart

357.92.text: because the act of recounting a direct experience transforms it into another currency.

362.42.text: It now becomes a story, an unsubstantiated claim.

366.42.text:
This instantly nullifies its evidential value.
Nothing is proved by an unsubstantiated claim.

372.84.text: To restore its value, substantiation is required.

375.80.text: But that’s the very thing denied to the common people.

378.98.text: Obviously, if you want to play dirty

381.04.text:
you can get the common people
to accept your revelation claims

386.42.text:
You just drill it into them, from birth if
possible, that your religion is perfect

392.64.text:
You fill their minds with visions of dreamy rewards
and nightmarish punishments.

396.84.text: And you make doubt a thought-crime.

399.36.text: The end result is generally a pleasingly compliant devotee who’ll swallow all your unsubstantiated claims

404.78.text: while scoffing at those of other religions.

407.16.text:
The problem is while you’re busy manipulating
people into your religion

410.66.text: other folks are manipulating people into theirs

413.18.text: creating followers who’ll favour their revelation stories and become impervious to yours.

418.84.text: Which leads us to a deeper problem.

421.08.text:
Divine characters like Allah and Yahweh are
conceptualised as all-knowing.

426.32.text:
If they existed, they’d know that people
indoctrinated into other religions

430.42.text:
are generally immune to all but
their own religion’s revelation stories.

434.24.text:
They would therefore also know that to get
through to those people in other religions,

438.11.text:
a much more powerful method of persuasion
was needed than revelation stories

442.49.text:
— ie proof that has the power to transcend
all religious biases and barriers.

447.87.text: Proof that has the power to reach every individual.

451.25.text:
For all the centuries of lip-flapping
about all-powerful gods

455.16.text: not one single religion has produced the goods.

460.75.text:
every single one of them has instead required
their followers to take their word for it.

465.96.text: So, in the absence of proof, what do we have?

469.70.text: Here we come the biggest problem so far.

472.34.text: Taking just Islam and Christianity, in both cases

476.00.text:
we have a divine character who’s
content to do nothing

478.76.text:
while millions of human beings,
through no fault or desire of their own

485.20.text:
It knows that this indoctrination will create
powerful biases in those humans

491.54.text:
It then watches as these humans descend
to unspeakable torment in hell

498.40.text: What we’re talking about is a holocaust bystander.

502.14.text:
To describe this behaviour as ‘callous’
limboes beneath understatement.

506.78.text: But what I want to highlight is its sheer stupidity.

510.00.text:
Imagine the following situation.
You’re a night security guard for an apartment block.

514.92.text: You’re stationed in a small hut attached to the block

517.44.text: with CCTV screens and speaker access to all areas.

521.28.text:
There’s a fire in the building that forces
everyone down to a basement area

525.12.text: where they find a red door and a yellow door.

528.16.text: They debate which one to take.

530.14.text: They can hear traffic noises behind the yellow door.

533.02.text:
But then someone sees the faded word ‘EXIT’
above the red door.

537.30.text:
The group becomes sharply divided
into Reds and Yellows

540.64.text: each rejecting the arguments of the other.

542.80.text: You watch all of this on your CCTV screen,

545.52.text: knowing that the red door leads to freedom

547.66.text:
while the yellow door leads
to a dead-end and certain death.

551.12.text:
There’s a vent next to your desk
connected to a vent in the basement.

555.46.text: You can see that one of the Reds is standing near it.

558.12.text: If you shout down the vent ‘Take the red door’

560.90.text:
she’ll just about hear you and she’ll report
receiving advice from a disembodied voice.

566.20.text: You know the Reds are already predisposed to believe her.

569.80.text:
But you also know the Yellows will easily
dismiss this ridiculous ghostly message.

575.36.text:
Alternatively, you could use
the public address system at your disposal

579.08.text: to give an announcement over the basement speakers that’ll be clearly heard by everyone

583.24.text: identifying yourself as the guard from the security hut and telling them to take the red door.

589.64.text: So, do you choose the vent or the PA system?

595.36.text: Allah and Yahweh chose the vent.

602.36.text: But the ill-conceived system of private revelation employed by prophet-based religions

606.58.text:
has the grubby fingerprints
of limited human thinking all over it.

609.74.text: If you want to overcome the doubts of serious thinkers

614.18.text: you seriously need to up your game.

620.46.text:
Many religious people suffer with
tremendous guilt about their doubts.

624.36.text: — guilt that’s often inspired and reinforced by others

628.88.text:
In his book ‘God in the dark: The assurance
of faith beyond a shadow of doubt’,

633.36.text: Christian author Os Guinness identifies nine kinds of doubt that he suggests lead people out of faith

638.98.text:
all of which put the blame
squarely on the doubter.

642.02.text:
He talks about doubt from ingratitude,
from a faulty view of his god Yahweh,

646.76.text:
from weak foundations, from lack of commitment, 
from lack of growth, from unruly emotion,

653.44.text:
from hidden conflicts, from inquisitiveness 
and from impatience.

658.22.text:
The possibility that doubt could come from
inconsistencies is dogmatically dismissed.

663.38.text: Scare-mongering imagery is used throughout the book.

666.62.text:
For example, a nameless doubt
is compared to a ‘waiting shark’

672.82.text: with ‘no limit to its shadowy potential for destruction’.

675.96.text:
Guinness warns that preoccupation with doubt
holds ‘much danger’

679.54.text: comparing it to preoccupation with sickness.

682.20.text:
But preoccupation in both these areas
can lead to positive outcomes.

685.88.text: With sickness, preoccupation can lead to effective treatments.

689.56.text:
With doubt, preoccupation can expose deception,
expand our knowledge and free us from tyranny.

695.92.text:
Later on, I’ll be talking about
the dangers of not doubting

699.26.text:
and I won’t be resorting to hyperbole,
but offering real-life examples.

703.76.text:
All these criticisms of religious doubters
are ones many of us have heard before.

708.06.text:
The charge of ingratitude was levelled at me
when I expressed my own religious doubts as a child.

712.88.text: I pled — and still plead — not guilty.

715.80.text:
It wasn’t that I became ungrateful.
I was just putting my gratitude where it belonged.

720.96.text:
For instance, after the recovery of loved
ones from life-threatening accidents or illness,

725.80.text:
while some folks have busied themselves telling
everyone about the thanks they gave to their god.

730.38.text:
you would’ve found me thanking
the doctors and nurses.

733.54.text:
You know? The folks who actually saved
those lives, with their knowledge and dedication.

738.76.text:
Sometimes a sense of gratitude can be experienced
without the need to direct it towards any agent

745.28.text: When I’m filling the kettle or standing under the shower,

748.14.text:
I’m intensely mindful of the fact that access
to running water is a tremendous luxury

752.64.text: unknown to vast numbers of humans.

755.68.text:
When I’m sprinting, either to make up time
or for the sheer joy of it

759.62.text: I feel deep appreciation for the physical mobility I enjoy.

763.54.text: And when I experience doubt — even crushing doubt —

767.16.text:
I treasure my fundamental freedom
to think for myself.

771.98.text:
For many folks, doubts about their religion
get stirred up by distressing life events

781.30.text:
At these times, when many cry out ‘Why, Oh Lord?’
and crave robust answers

787.08.text:
it seems all religions have to offer
is a welter of mimsy platitudes.

792.12.text:
People are told: ‘God doesn’t give us
anything we can’t handle.’

798.40.text:
When people take their own lives to escape
some anguish

801.42.text: whether that anguish comes from chronic pain, relentless bullying, insufferable loss

806.72.text: or an inability to construct a future

809.62.text:
they have, by definition, been given more
than they could handle.

814.18.text:
People are told: ‘God doesn’t give you the people
you want. He gives you the people you need.’

819.44.text: In rebuttal, again one word: pedophile.

822.58.text: Is anyone seriously going to argue

824.56.text: that their god gave sexually-abused children the paedophiles they needed?

829.10.text:
Guinness characterises the question ‘Why, Oh Lord?’
as ‘doubt from impatient inquisitiveness’

834.38.text:
and puts the doubter’s need to know
down to a lack of trust.

841.80.text:
Leaving gods aside, let’s consider
our real relationships with other humans

846.30.text: specifically, with the people we most trust in the world.

849.98.text:
When we ask them questions
about their actions and intentions,

853.36.text:
does that mean that we’re impatiently inquisitive,
or that we lack trust in them?

859.06.text: In fact, very often it’s when we trust people most deeply

862.48.text:
that we feel most confident about
approaching them with troubling inconsistencies.

866.80.text:
We trust that they’ll understand the genuine
concern behind our questions.

871.12.text:
We trust they’ll be able and willing to
clear things up.

874.82.text:
But most of all we trust that they won’t
respond with abuse and emotional blackmail,

881.86.text:
In fact, it’s when people behave in these defensive
and attacking ways that alarms bells start ringing.

888.00.text:
The tragedy isn’t that Christian doubters
lack trust, but often that they have so much trust.

893.84.text:
Religious apologists might try to whip up
all kinds of scare-mongering rhetoric

897.92.text: and emotional blackmail to make doubts seem shameful and dangerous.

902.26.text: But doubt is a perfectly healthy response

905.24.text:
when we perceive problems
in the information we’re working with

908.14.text:
and there’s no reason to feel guilty
for wanting to address those problems.

912.52.text:
As for danger, that comes not when we start
to doubt, but when we stop doubting.

917.87.text:
HBO’s documentary ‘Mea Maxima Culpa 
— Silence in the House of God’

922.35.text:
showed how religious suppression
of doubt played several key roles

925.69.text: in the perpetuation of child sexual abuse by Catholic priests.

929.19.text: For some victims, the status of the priest as a divine agent put his motives and actions beyond doubt.

934.98.text:
They therefore accepted the abuse,
figuring they must deserve it.

938.84.text: Other victims who did seek help found it was the adults they confided in — from parents to police —

944.36.text: who refused to doubt the ‘holy fathers’.

946.90.text:
It’s hard for some folks to grasp
the height of the pedestal

950.10.text:
on which the Catholic clergy
were placed in these cases.

953.24.text:
Ordained priests were considered
to be transformed into semi-divine humans.

958.14.text: One victim of Roman Catholic priest Alexander Walsh

961.62.text:
reportedly believed he was being touched
by the hand of god.

965.36.text:
Priests are attributed with the divine power
of transubstantiation —

968.96.text: the purported ability to turn wafers and wine into the body and blood of the Christian messiah Jesus.

974.56.text:
In some cases, consecrated wafers were reportedly
pressed against the genitals of victims.

980.38.text:
Priests are also attributed with the power
to grant absolution, the forgiveness of mortal sins.

986.18.text: Some priests used absolution as divine justification for their crimes

990.68.text:
claiming they were taking
the children’s sins on themselves.

994.10.text:
Absolution could also be used in a more coercive
way, by being withheld if victims didn’t submit.

1000.28.text:
The church’s aversion to doubt
also played a more far-reaching role.

1004.16.text: In a scandal that alienated countless Catholics,

1007.14.text:
it was discovered that the Vatican had long
known

1009.38.text:
about the endemic problem
of child sexual abuse within its ranks.

1014.76.text:
a religious organisation that also sees itself
as above the reach of worldly laws

1019.00.text: and has maintained a secret database of known and suspected pedophiles within its membership,

1024.26.text: the Catholic church also had extensively documented knowledge of offenders which it concealed for years.

1031.02.text:
Victims might be privately paid off, sworn
to secrecy

1036.34.text:
even coerced into signing official apologies for
the true allegations made against their abusers

1044.42.text: To preserve unquestioning trust in the church.

1049.48.text:
Some apologists assert that Yahweh has nothing
to do with this unholy mess;

1054.28.text:
that these are human acts
for which he’s unaccountable.

1058.16.text: But Yahweh isn’t so easily absolved.

1062.70.text: According to the Bible, Jesus chose to spread his word

1065.66.text:
not through an egalitarian system
of universal revelation to every individual,

1070.09.text:
but through an elitist system of specially
appointed agents called disciples.

1076.17.text:
The Catholic clergy — from priest to bishop
to pope — continues this legacy of discipleship.

1083.61.text:
In Luke 10 verse 16, Jesus tells the disciples:
‘Whoever listens to you listens to me’.

1090.15.text:
More pointedly he continues: ‘.... whoever
rejects you rejects me’.

1095.23.text:
And just to really drive the point home, he
adds that whoever rejects him rejects Yahweh.

1100.99.text:
So, cutting out the middle Messiah, reject
Yahweh’s disciples and you reject Yahweh.

1107.63.text: By introducing this system of elite disciples

1110.57.text:
that the common people are directed to trust
as Yahweh’s representatives,

1114.66.text:
Yahweh becomes implicated in any abuses
that result from the misuse of that trust.

1121.60.text:
able to foresee every abuse that would result
from this elitist system

1128.90.text: If he existed, he would absolutely be accountable.

1133.06.text: Child sexual abuse occurs in all kinds of institutions.

1136.44.text: But the religious suppression of doubt

1138.66.text:
has given priests a level of immunity
other sexual predators could only dream of

1143.36.text:
allowing some to prey
on hundreds of children over decades

1147.28.text: under the protection of a church more concerned with its holy reputation than the suffering of its victims.

1154.28.text:
Guinness conceptualised
a nameless doubt as a ‘waiting shark’

1158.26.text: with ‘no limit to its shadowy potential for destruction’.

1163.88.text:
Doubt is what allows us
to spot the sharks around us:

1167.22.text:
the deceivers, the manipulators and the abusers
who thrive in spaces that suppress doubt.

1175.70.text: Doubt can sometimes put us in a spin.

1178.62.text:
But lack of doubt leaves us
vulnerable to the spin of others.

1182.16.text: The hollow metaphors, the deflections, the doublespeak

1186.22.text:
and the emotional blackmail of those who wish
to forcibly confine us in their ideology

1190.86.text: rather than try to persuade us respectfully.

1193.84.text: Doubt is the the path out of that confinement.

1196.98.text:
Ideologies that demand
their followers neither know nor doubt

1200.52.text:
put those followers in
an impossible psychological position,

1203.68.text: denying them both certainty and uncertainty.

1207.30.text: Sadly, there are still many parts of the world

1209.92.text: where voicing doubts will attract officially condoned punishments up to and including execution.

1215.70.text:
They might silence some of our mouths,
but we should never let them silence our minds.

1223.29.text:
This quote, attributed to Socrates, reminds
us that when we allow others to think for us

1228.44.text:
what we’ll find in our heads are their ideas,
their perceptions, their experiences, their beliefs

1237.30.text:
To find ourselves, we need
to exercise our freedom to think

1241.58.text:
and resist ideologies that try to block that freedom
by punishing doubt.
